grounding: Current digital health approaches have not engaged diverse end users or reduced health or health care inequities, despite their promise to deliver more tailored and personalized support to individuals at the right time and the right place. To achieve digital health equity, we must refocus our attention on the current state of digital health uptake and use across the policy, system, community, individual, and intervention levels. We focus here on (a) outlining a multilevel framework underlying digital health equity; (b) summarizingfive types of interventions/programs (with example studies) that hold promise for advancing digital health equity; and (c) recommending future steps for improving policy, practice, and research in this space.
generated_text: This literature synthesis explores the multilevel determinants of digital health equity, integrating findings from a comprehensive review of scientific literature. It identifies key factors at individual, community, and systemic levels that influence equitable access to and utilization of digital health technologies. The study highlights the interplay between social determinants of health and technological advancements, emphasizing the need for inclusive design and policy interventions to address disparities. By synthesizing evidence across disciplines, this research aims to advance the field of digital health equity, offering insights for stakeholders to develop strategies that ensure all populations benefit from health technology innovations, thereby contributing to the reduction of health disparities globally.
